'''''Lactarius xanthogalactus''''', commonly known as the '''yellow-staining milkcap''' is a [[Mushroom poisoning|poisonous]] species of [[fungus]] in the family [[Russulaceae]]. It produces [[mushroom]]s with pinkish-cinnamon [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] up to {{convert|11|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide held by pinkish-white [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] up to {{convert|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} long.  When it is cut or injured, the mushroom oozes a white [[latex]] that rapidly turns bright sulfur-yellow. The species is found on the west coast of the United States and grows in the ground in association with [[hardwood]] and [[conifer]] trees. There are several other ''Lactarius'' species that bear resemblance to ''L. xanthogalactus'', but most can be distinguished by differences in [[staining]] reactions, macroscopic characteristics, or habitat.

==Taxonomy and classification==
The species was first [[species description|described]] by American mycologist [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1907.<ref name="Peck 1907"/>

The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''xanthogalactus'' is derived from the [[Latin]] words meaning "yellow" and "milk".

==Similar species==
[[File:Lactarius chrysorrheus 041120w.jpg|thumb|160px|right|''Lactarius chrysorrheus'' also produces yellow latex.]]
''[[Lactarius vinaceorufescens]]'' has nearly identical microscopic features to ''L. xanthogalactus'', but macroscopically it has reddish-vinaceous stains that develop on the cap, gills, and stem.  Another lookalike is ''[[Lactarius colorascens|L. colorascens]]'', but it may be distinguished from ''L. xanthogalactus'' by several features: a smaller fruit body; a whitish cap that becomes brownish-red with age and does not spot vinaceous or brown; bitter to faintly acrid latex; and slightly smaller spores. ''[[Lactarius chrysorrheus|L. chrysorrheus]]'' is also similar, but it has a whitish to pale yellowish-cinnamon cap with slightly darker spots and grows under hardwoods (especially oak) on well-drained, often sandy soil, and its gills do not discolor or spot vinaceous or brown.<ref name=Bessette2009/>

Other superficially similar species include ''[[Lactarius rubrilacteus|L. rubrilacteus]]'', ''[[Lactarius rufus|L. rufus]]'', ''[[Lactarius subviscidus|L. subviscidus]]'', ''[[Lactarius fragilis|L. fragilis]]'' and ''[[Lactarius rufulus|L. rufulus]]'', but none of these species have the yellow staining reaction characteristic of ''L. xanthogalactus''.<ref name=Arora1986/>

==Habitat and distribution==
The fruit bodies of ''Lactarius xanthogalactus'' grow scattered or in groups on the ground under [[conifers]] and [[hardwoods]] between August and January in [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Oregon]] and [[California]].
